Award.AwardTitle: Dissociative Photodetachment Dynamics of Multiply Charged Anions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanism (CSDM-A) Program in the Division of Chemistry supports Dr. Robert Continetti at the University of California-San Diego in his studies of isolated multiply charged anions. These molecules with extra electrons play an important role in a wide range of chemistry, including biological systems, catalysts and as building blocks in ionic solids. However, they are very difficult to study experimentally in an isolated state. This research program involves novel measurements of the stability and chemistry of isolated multiply charged anions, with the information gained providing new insights and guiding the development of an improved theoretical understanding of these important chemical building blocks. Students involved in this project are learning about the design, construction and chemical application of a unique apparatus. The PI also uses contacts with local industry in San Diego (Cymer, Illumina, Air Products and others) to arrange quarterly tours of industrial labs and seminars by industrial scientists to enhance the career development of underrepresented minority and women graduate students across the Dept. of Chemistry and Biochemistry at UCSD.

On a more technical level, this award enables experimental studies of the energetics, photochemistry and dissociation dynamics of multiply charged anions (MCAs) with a particular focus on dissociative photodetachment. Isolated MCAs are challenging systems for study theoretically and experimentally, but important progress has been made using photoelectron and photodissociation spectroscopies. However, many MCAs can undergo complex multiple photodetachment and dissociation processes. These studies use an electrospray ionization source coupled with a cryogenic accumulator ion trap prior to injection into a high-energy electrostatic ion beam trap where the photoelectron and photofragment measurements are made. Time- and position-sensitive detectors are used to make three-dimensional, kinematically complete measurements of the photodetachment, multiple photodetachment, photodissociation and dissociative photodetachment processes observed. In addition, the lifetimes of metastable polyanions and photofragment anions are measured in the electrostatic ion beam trap. The first focus of the project is on the stable dianions formed from dicarboxylic acids, later to be extended to phthalocyanines and biologically relevant sulfonates. In a collaboration with the synthetic inorganic laboratory of Figueroa at UCSD, novel metal carbonyl and isocyanide complexes synthesized for applications in catalysis are also under study. For these systems, there is no prior experimental information available on the ligand dissociation processes and electron-capture energetics that this project is providing. This information is essential for guiding the design of future catalysts and the development of an improved theory of MCAs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the development of a new experimental apparatus for the study of fundamental properties of complex negative molecular ions in the gas phase, and the use of photodetachment of those negative ions as a tool for understanding the reactivity and energetics of the corresponding neutral molecules. As an example of the types of molecules of interest, consider the carboxylic acids and their derivatives that play a key role in the oxidation of organic compounds in systems that range from biological, to combustion, to environmental chemistry, yet are often poorly understood at a fundamental level. The underlying principle behind the measurements made under this project is straightforward – excite the negative ion with a photon, and observe how it breaks up into a free electron and neutral reaction products, and detect all of those products at the same time – in coincidence. This is called a photoelectron-photofragment coincidence experiment, and it is a unique type of measurement pioneered in this laboratory. This simplicity of the principle behind the measurement hides the fact that executing measurements like this on heavy and complex negative ions is difficult for a number of reasons. One of the most important is that the neutral molecules produced from heavy negative ions will in general be moving too slowly to be detected efficiently by impact on the surface of the particle detector. This challenge was solved in this project by borrowing a technique from high energy physics – use of a linear accelerator, where the same electric potential difference is used over and over again to accelerate the negative ion to higher energies.

The project achieved this experimental goal, achieving beam energies up to 31 kiloelectron volts, more than three times higher than previously available. The postdoctoral fellow and graduate and undergraduate students working on the project demonstrated the method by studying heavy negative ions including two-atom and three-atom halogen negative ions (halides). Then, they extended the technique to the negative ion produced from the simplest of the dicarboxylic acids – oxalic acid. This molecule, composed of two organic acid carboxylic groups (-COOH) bonded together (HOOC-COOH), was studied by making the monoanion, by removing one of the protons (H+). It was found that when the electron was removed from that monoanion that the molecule essentially exploded, with a high release of kinetic energy, producing the very stable molecular carbon dioxide in conjunction with a hydrocarboxyl radical, HOCO.

The intrinsic value of this work lies in the development of a new technique for experimental studies of more complex molecular negative ions than previously possible. The data obtained in these studies provides new insights into energetics and reactivity and experimental benchmarks against which theoretical predictions about the energetics and reactivity of molecular negative ions and neutral radicals and molecule can be evaluated. The broader scientific impacts include an expanded knowledge of the photochemistry of halogen compounds, carboxylate anions and their clusters with implications ranging from biology to atmospheric and combustion chemistry.

One of the most important broader impacts of this work is the training it provides researchers at all levels. Designing, building and demonstrating state-of-the-art scientific equipment provides outstanding training for the scientists of tomorrow who will help solve society’s many challenging problems that require scientific input. Beyond training in the lab, as part of this grant the PI also carried out a program of tours for a broader graduate student cohort (20-25 students) to local industries, including Vertex Pharmaceuticals, the DNA sequencing company Illumina, and the semiconductor photolithography firm Cymer/ASML. This outreach effort provided graduate students a broader perspective on career opportunities beyond graduate school, and has already led to some new hires of Ph.D. chemists by local industry.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2019
Modified by: Robert E Continetti
